top_comment.text: What's your opinion on braided line with a flouro leader?﻿
top_comment.author: Elitellamaryder

comments.text:
+Elitellamaryder Heavy braided line will still have a relatively thin 
diameter. But I would stick with 14 to 16-pound straight fluorocarbon and 
run with it. Can't go wrong!
comments.author: Walker Smith

comments.text:
+Walker Smith Thank You!! I'm currently in a bit of a situation. See I've 
only ever used mono my whole life so I'm new to everything else. I 
currently use a Pinnacle Platinum plus rod and reel combo baitcaster and 
with my 10lb test .30mm Spiderwire mono I cant cast far at all and its not 
sensitive so I cant feel any structure, so I want to switch to a more 
baitcaster friendly line. And with braids thin diameter it seems like the 
way to go, but from what I've heard you need to go heavier test with braid 
which will give me a thicker diameter. And I've heard straight mono can 
have bad memory problems. So as you can see I'm in a bit of a pickle. Any 
advice you can give me will be greatly appreciated. I've been searching for 
answer for weeks. Thank you!!
comments.author: Elitellamaryder

comments.text:
I definitely recommend it for finesse tactics, but for flipping and 
pitching shallow cover, I tend to steer away from it. Because most of your 
hooksets will be powerful in order to wrench the bass away from the cover, 
I think having that extra line-to-line knot gives drastically increases 
your chances of breaking off. It's just one more potential "failure point" 
in this situation. I'd go with straight 16 to 20-pound fluorocarbon or 
straight 50 to 65-pound braided line. Thanks for watching!
comments.author: Walker Smith

top_comment.text:
Thanks Walker, great info. Just curious, why do you recommend a 7' rod for 
shorter people, and 7'6 for tall people. Seems like short people would need 
the extra advantage of a longer rod. A lot of guys go with 20-25lb 
fluorocarbon and7'6- 8' rods for the extra security and power when horsing 
out big fish from the thick stuff. 

Also, how do you feel about using snell knots on a flipping hook? The hook 
gets better penetration compared to an EWG. I think the only advantage of 
EWG is you're basically guaranteed weedless. Hook point of a flipping hook 
will come out once in a while. 
-Zach﻿
top_comment.author: zachbrooksher

comments.text: Cool, thanks for your response. That makes perfect sense.
comments.author: zachbrooksher

comments.text:
When shorter folks use longer rods to pitch and flip, the rod tip will 
often slap the water or the side of the boat. In my experience guiding 
fishing trips, I've noticed a large increase in accuracy when anglers use 
the "correct" rod length that matches their height. The heavier line is a 
good idea and I definitely don't advise against it. Either way will work 
just fine!
comments.author: Walker Smith

captions.text:
If you take one look around me right now all
around this boat is nothing but shallow cover.

Throughout the entire country it means big
bass. I grew up fishing in Georgia. A lot

of muddy water shallow type fisheries. It's
hard to beat flippin' and pitching soft plastics
for big bass.

When you're working down a stretch of bank
you're going to look for something that looks

a little bit different than everything else.
We've got a bunch of bushes back there and

they look sexy, but they're in about 4 inches
of water. Not the best depth for catching

big bass. So what I like to do is target pieces
that come out just a little bit further. So

we've got 6 inches back here, the boat is
in 3 and half feet, and these bushes right

here on the outside are in probably about
2 or 2 and half feet. Look for something different.

Bass love an edge and that's why I target
edges. It gives them something to orient to

as they move to and from shallow water. Just
pick it apart. I mean if you're not convinced

there's not a fish somewhere you just casted
cast again. It's about being efficient to

though. I mean you've got to just go through
here and just go to work. Keep your head down

and just keep fishing. When I'm in super shallow
cover I'll just flip it in there, lift it

about two or three times, and if it doesn't
bite it by then its lost its chance. Now they're

are sometimes where that changes. But that's
primarily what works best for me.

So there's not a better feeling in bass fishing
than flippin' into heavy cover, feeling that

thump, seeing your line swim off,
and setting the hook into something solid.

I love jig fishing and I catch a lot of big
fish on jigs. But the most consistent technique

day in and day out is flippin' soft plastic
baits.

Now when you walk down the isle of your favorite
tackle store whatever it may be. You're going

to see bags, bags, bags, and probably more
bags of all these soft plastics. This one

is going to say it's the best and so is this
one so it's really hard to choose. But in

my opinion you can break it down into four
categories that's going to make it your purchasing

easier, and I think you'll catch more fish
with it.

Now these four categories I like to use are
both for application and storage. You can

store it a little bit more modularly, and
pick through it easier to find what you need

without having to shuffle through your entire
boat.

I really like to use crawfish type soft plastics
in situations of course where you might think

there is crawfish around. Now those situations
are times like a full moon. A couple days

before and after a full moon you're going
to have a lot of crawfish come out of rocks,

deep brush piles, around the bank, and the
bass eat those. It's a great source of protein

for bass. Craw baits like this will work any
day really. It's just a really good staple

that if you flip it to enough trees and blow
downs you'll catch fish.

I also like to use lizards. People think that
the lizard is a springtime only type deal.

Now it's at its best in the spring. But you
can absolute whack em' on this throughout

the entire year. You can flip this thing underneath
docks, to grass lines, and you can even swim

it through heavier vegetation on a light Texas
Rig. So it's very versatile and allows you

to get to the fish easily. I mean a bass cannot
stand the sight of these things so this is
always a great choice.

For my heavier cover presentations like when
I'm in very thick grass when I'm trying to

penetrate cover and get down to the bottom
where those fish are sitting I like to use

very slender beaver baits. Like this Missile
Baits D-bomb that's what this one is. It doesn't

have many appendages, you'll notice it's very
smooth, and it doesn't have a lot of noise

more or less to get caught on branches or
grass strands. So when you're trying to get

into really small areas you can squeeze this
little dude into anywhere. You can get to

those fish on high sky days when it's really
sunny and they're tucked in really tight to
cover.

Finally, when I'm looking for a big bite and
they won't eat that jig I like creature baits

and that's what I call these. This happens
to be a ZOOM Brush Hog. They're larger; they

put off a lot of vibration in the water, and
a lot of displacement. So when this thing

is falling these ribbon tails are just twirling
through the water like that. When you twitch

it you've got these side paddles making movement
undulating down there. So this is a great

big fish bait and I really like it in the
summer months as well.

Now you see these guys throwing these big
ol' 10-inch worms in the summer and you think

well what does that really imitate because
I've never seen an earth worm that long? They

actually imitate a lot of leeches and even
smaller snakes. It sounds crazy but it's true.

Now this big profile can also do that in the
summer. So if you've got deeper docks (by

deeper I mean 6-8 feet off the end) leading
into a very shallow area this is a great choice
for it.

Another good tip for flippin' and pitching
shallow cover is to wear polarized glasses

of some sort because you'll see some stuff
in the water that a lot of guys are going

to miss. Any isolated pieces of wood out from
the stuff everybody else hits is a good idea

because the sexier the cover looks, the more
people are going to fish it. You're not the

only one that has found it I can almost guarantee
you that.

You've kind of got to think outside the box
a little bit.

When you're pitching and flippin' soft plastics
in the shallow cover a great starting point

is far as a reel is a 7:1:1 gear ratio. It's
quick enough to get the fish out of the cover

and if it runs to the boat you can take up
line quickly. You can go up to 8:1 and you

can even go up to 9:1 these days. But 7:1
will keep you covered. For your rod I suggest

either a 7' for shorter guys or a 7'6 for
taller folks. Medium heavy-to-heavy action,

whatever allows you to cast best and get the
fish out of your specific cover on your home

fishery. As far a line selection you want
it heavy and you don't want a lot of stretch

in it either. So that's why I'm going to pick
a 16-20 pound fluorocarbon line. It's got

low stretch and the fish can't see it. So
when they bite you can yank them out of the

crud without having to wrestle with them too
much.

Your hook selection is also critical with
this technique. I suggest going out and getting

you a few packs of 3/0-5/0 hooks. You can
choose between two types: You can choose between

extra wide gap (EWG) which are better for
bigger creature baits that have a little bit

more meat on them. You'll get better hook
penetration sometimes and that's pretty much

what I use is the EWG's for. Now for the smaller
more compact flippin' baits I like to use

just a straight shank flippin' hook. A lot
of company's make some really cool ones and

like I said 3/0-4/0. Now these straight shank
flippin' hooks are great for flippin' into

small areas because when you set the hook
this dude is pretty mean. He's going to come

straight up and stick right there in the hard
part of that fishes mouth and that's where
you want to hook them.
